text.headline:
Patient Pathways Interactive
Patient A
text.text: Instructions: You can view the progression in a linear fashion by using the left and right arrows on desktop or swipe on mobile. Additionally, you can slide the timeline to move forward or back in time. Use the magnifying glass to scale the timeline as needed

text.headline: Presentation / ER
text.text:
• 19 year old female patient presented to ED
  • 5/7 vomiting,fevers,intermittent abdominal pain,myalgia,weakness

Vital signs

  • RR 22/min,Sats 94% O2
  • HR 140-150 bpm SR
  • GCS 15/15

Past medical History

  • 6 weeks ago came to UK from Brazil
  • Partner witnessed that she c/o palpitations occasionally & joint pains

fig: ECG

fig: CXR

Escalation of management

On presentation she was in extremis:she was hypoxic,acidotic and hypotensive and therefore she was referred for ECMO

  • PH 7.30(7.35-7.45)
  • PCO2 5.88(4.5-6)
  • PO2 11.9(9.5-14)
  • HCO3 20.9(22-30)

What investigations should take place next?

Go to the next slide (click on the arrow to the right)

text.headline: ICU Imaging
text.text:
Computed tomography demonstrated the following findings:

  • Suspected subdural haemorrhage: a small linear area of high density in the right parafalcine region: differentials include a small subdural hematoma or a small thrombus within a tributary in the superior sagittal sinus.
  • No pulmonary embolism
  • Dense consolidation throughout both lungs bilaterally with only a small area of the aerated lung on the right.
  • The airways are completely collapsed approximately 9 mm distal to the endotracheal tube.
  • Bilateral renal and splenic infarcts
  • Bilateral periportal oedema and moderate volume ascites.

fig: JIp01_02ICU_CT1

fig: JIp01_02ICU_CT2

What do you think is happening?

fig: JIp01_02ICU_CT2

    o JIp01_02ICU_labs1 [Normal values still to be inserted]
  • lab 1
  • lab 2

What should you do next?

Description of the bedside echocardiography findings:

  • Echo 1: Parasternal long axis demonstrates extensive lung consolidation and you can see that there are extensive vegetations on the mitral valve, starting from the posterior leaflet. The vegetation has affected the posterior leaflet which is prolapsing slightly into the left atrium.
  • Echo 2: Then we adjust the depth to better view the mitral valve.
  • Echo 3: We notice a degree of mitral regurgitation due to the vegetation on the posterior leaflet.
  • Echo 4: On parasternal long axis of right ventricular inflow there is a suspected vegetation on the right ventricle close to the tricuspid papillary muscle.
  • Echos 5&6: Parasternal short axis demonstrates extensive vegetations on the right ventricular wall. Both views are “off axis” to demonstrate both mitral and right ventricular wall vegetations.
  • Echo 7: On parasternal short axis with colour Doppler it is evident that there is at least moderate eccentric mitral regurgitation.
  • Echo 8: Apical four chamber view demonstrates normal size left and right ventricles. There is a vegetation on the posterior leaflet which prolapse.
  • Echo 9: A zoom on the mitral valve with colour Doppler demonstrates at least moderate eccentric mitral regurgitation.
  • Echo 10: The zoom view of the mitral valve demonstrates the vegetation on the posterior leaflet.

fig: Echo1:

Parasternal long axis demonstrates extensive lung consolidation and you can see that there are extensive vegetations on the mitral valve, starting from the posterior leaflet. The vegetation has affected the posterior leaflet which is prolapsing slightly into the left atrium.

fig: Echo2:

Then we adjust the depth to better view the mitral valve.

fig: Echo3:

We notice a degree of mitral regurgitation due to the vegetation on the posterior leaflet.

fig: Echo4:

On parasternal long axis of right ventricular inflow there is a suspected vegetation on the right ventricle close to the tricuspid papillary muscle.

fig: Echo5 & Echo 6:

Parasternal short axis demonstrates extensive vegetations on the right ventricular wall. Both views are “off axis” to demonstrate both mitral and right ventricular wall vegetations.

fig: Echo7:

On parasternal short axis with colour Doppler it is evident that there is at least moderate eccentric mitral regurgitation.

fig: Echo8:

Apical four chamber view demonstrates normal size left and right ventricles. There is a vegetation on the posterior leaflet which prolapse.

fig: Echo9:

A zoom on the mitral valve with colour Doppler demonstrates at least moderate eccentric mitral regurgitation.

fig: Echo10:

The zoom view of the mitral valve demonstrates the vegetation on the posterior leaflet.

ICU Labs 2

  • Hb 80
  • Platelets 50
  • Fibrinogen 2
  • INR 1.2

Arterial blood gas values:

  • pH 7.346
  • pCO2 5.88
  • pO2 9.9
  • SB 22.6
  • BE -2.0
  • FiO2 40%
  • LACT 0.8

The patient was in disseminated intravascular coagulation and, taking the small subdural hematoma into consideration, heparin was stopped and antithrombin and a pool of platelets were given. The patient was also started on antibiotics: Tazocin, linezolid, clarithromycin and a stat dose of gentamycin

When should we operate?

Dr. Blauth and the video from ICU with Dr. Grapsa.

Go to the next slide (click on the arrow to the right)
